Primary_Reference: Weiner, J.S., 1962. The pattern of evolutionary development of the genus Homo. In Ideas on Human Evolution: Selected Essays, 1949–1961 (pp. 521–532). Harvard University Press.
Recent_Reference: Ponce de León, M.S. et al., 2021. The primitive brain of early Homo. Science 372(6538): 165–171.
Dating_Rationale: Deep-time estimate expressed in years BP; point estimate used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: ~3 Ma. Approximate timing for earliest Homo (ca. 3 Ma) reported in paleoanthropological literature.

Primary_Reference: Binford, S.R. & Binford, L.R., 1969. Stone tools and human behavior. Scientific American 220(4): 70–87.
Recent_Reference: Lewis, J.E. & Harmand, S., 2016. An earlier origin for stone tool making: implications for cognitive evolution and the transition to Homo. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B 371(1698): 20150233.
Dating_Rationale: Deep-time estimate expressed in years BP; point estimate used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: ~2.5 Ma. Oldowan and early lithic traditions (approx.).

Primary_Reference: Rehder, J.E., 2000. Mastery and uses of fire in antiquity. McGill-Queen's University Press.
Recent_Reference: McLauchlan, K.K. et al., 2020. Fire as a fundamental ecological process: research advances and frontiers. Journal of Ecology 108(5): 2047–2069.
Dating_Rationale: Deep-time estimate expressed in years BP; literature reports a range and both bounds are retained; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: 700–400 ka. Range reflects debate on habitual fire use.

Primary_Reference: Hughes, S.S., 1998. Getting to the point: evolutionary change in prehistoric weaponry. Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory 5(4): 345–408.
Recent_Reference: Lombardo, M.P. & Deaner, R.O., 2018. Born to throw: the ecological causes that shaped the evolution of throwing in humans. The Quarterly Review of Biology 93(1): 1–16.
Dating_Rationale: Deep-time estimate expressed in years BP; point estimate used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: ~300 ka. Milestone centered on biomechanical/cognitive implications of accurate throwing.

Node_Name: Symbolic Language, Art, and Shared Intentionality
Primary_Reference: Henshilwood, C.S. & Dubreuil, B., 2017. The Still Bay and Howiesons Poort, 77–59 ka: symbolic material culture and modern human origins. Current Anthropology 58(S16): S3–S27.
Recent_Reference: Finlayson, C., 2019. The smart Neanderthal: bird catching, cave art, and the cognitive revolution. Oxford University Press.
Dating_Rationale: Deep-time estimate expressed in years BP; literature reports a range and both bounds are retained; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: 50–30 ka. Approximate window for symbolic culture consolidation.

Primary_Reference: Bar-Yosef, O., 1998. On the nature of transitions: the Middle to Upper Palaeolithic and the Neolithic Revolution. Cambridge Archaeological Journal 8(2): 141–163.
Recent_Reference: Shavit, A. & Sharon, G., 2023. Can models of evolutionary transition clarify the debates over the Neolithic Revolution? Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B 378(1872): 20210413.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in BCE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP≈2025 + BCE_year). Where a range is given, bounds reflect literature window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: ~10,000 BCE. Single-point approximation anchored at 10,000 BCE.

Primary_Reference: Ur, J.A., 2014. Households and the emergence of cities in ancient Mesopotamia. Cambridge University Press.
Recent_Reference: Jessop, B., 2016. The state: past, present, future. Polity.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in BCE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP≈2025 + BCE_year). Where a range is given, bounds reflect literature window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: 4000–3000 BCE. Range reflects gradual urban/state formation across regions.

Primary_Reference: Senner, W.M. (Ed.), 1991. The origins of writing. University of Nebraska Press.
Recent_Reference: Schmandt-Besserat, D., 2018. The earliest precursor of writing. In Communication in History (pp. 5–14). Routledge.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in BCE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP≈2025 + BCE_year). Where a range is given, bounds reflect literature window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: ~3100 BCE. Anchored on earliest Mesopotamian writing systems (approx.).

Primary_Reference: Eisenstadt, S.N. (Ed.), 2012. The origins and diversity of axial age civilizations. SUNY Press.
Recent_Reference: Mullins, D.A. et al., 2018. A systematic assessment of “Axial Age” proposals using global comparative historical evidence. American Sociological Review 83(3): 596–626.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in BCE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP≈2025 + BCE_year). Where a range is given, bounds reflect literature window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: 6th–5th century BCE. Century-based dating; modeled as a range.

Node_Name: Formation and Diffusion of World Religions
Primary_Reference: Bellah, R.N., 1970. Religious evolution. In Readings in Social Evolution and Development (pp. 211–244). Pergamon.
Recent_Reference: Masuzawa, T., 2024. The invention of world religions. University of Chicago Press.
Dating_Rationale: Century-based estimate converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP≈2025 + BCE_year). Bounds represent the century window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: 1st–7th century CE. Range captures formation + diffusion dynamics across Eurasia.

Primary_Reference: McIntyre, J. et al., 2001. Does the brain model Newton's laws? Nature Neuroscience 4(7): 693–694.
Recent_Reference: Susskind, L., 2020. Complexity and Newton's laws. Frontiers in Physics 8: 262.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in CE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP=2025−CE_year). Point estimate anchored on canonical publication year.
Notes: Time_label: 1687 CE. Anchored on Principia (1687) as canonical publication date.

Primary_Reference: Messiah, A., 2014. Quantum mechanics. Courier Corporation.
Recent_Reference: Sakurai, J.J. & Napolitano, J., 2020. Modern quantum mechanics. Cambridge University Press.
Dating_Rationale: Calendar estimate in CE converted to BP using Present_Year=2025 (BP=2025−CE_year). Point estimate anchored on canonical publication year.
Notes: Time_label: ~1900 CE. Anchored on early 20th-century onset (Planck era).

Primary_Reference: Sichel, D.E., 1997. The computer revolution: an economic perspective. Brookings Institution Press.
Recent_Reference: Sloman, A., 2019. What else is there besides digital computation? In The Turing Guide (pp. 291–312). Oxford University Press.
Dating_Rationale: Era-labeled milestone operationalized as 1970–1990 CE; converted to BP with Present_Year=2025 (BP=2025−year). Range bounds reflect the operational window; median used for modeling.
Notes: Time_label: Late 20th Century. Broad-century label operationalized as 1970–1990 (microprocessor-to-personal computing era).

Primary_Reference: Makridakis, S., 2017. The forthcoming Artificial Intelligence (AI) revolution: its impact on society and firms. Futures 90: 46–60.
Recent_Reference: Afjal, M. et al., 2025. Artificial intelligence in robotics: a comprehensive review. Artificial Intelligence Review 58(2): 132.
Dating_Rationale: Operationalized within the manuscript's '21st Century (Early Stage)' label: mapped to 2010–2020 CE for numeric BP conversion under Present_Year_for_BP=2025; median used for modeling; adjust bounds if a different operational window is adopted.
Notes: Time_label: 21st Century (Early Stage). Numeric window set to 2010–2020 to avoid conflating the literature-review horizon (2019–2025) or the BP reference year (2025) with a milestone date. Note: the ~2035±W window reported in the paper is a model-extrapolated *future* transition window, not an input node timestamp.
